abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Basic Education
            Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, Bank
            performance as highly satisfactory, and Borrower performance
            as satisfactory. Three external factors had a substantial
            impact on project implementation: 1) the earthquake of April
            22, 1991; 2) the economic recession during 1995-1997, and 3)
            the contesting of contract awards by outside bidders. There
            are several lessons that can be learned from the project
            experience: Integration of quality education subcomponents
            require intensive coordination and additional implementation
            time. Public-private sector alliances increase project
            implementation capacity and effectiveness. Continuity of
            project implementing personnel is key to maintain
            satisfactory project execution, especially during and after
            changes in Government administration. Supervision and
            technical assistance must combine sectoral and
            administrative issues. To guarantee development objectives,
            projects must adapt to the changing needs of the education sector.

repnme.cdata!: Costa Rica - Basic Education Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project supports the
            Government's education sector strategy and priority
            programs, as outlined in the government's National
            Development Plan, 1990-94, and its General Plan for
            Education 1990-94. The Project comprises three main
            components.  (1) Improvements of the Quality of Basic
            Education would include: curriculum revision, the production
            and distribution of textbooks, in-service training programs
            for teachers and administrators, and improvements in
            physical infrastructure and facilities in the disadvantaged
            rural regions. (2) Strengthening of Sector Planning and
            Management specifically in the areas of personnel
            management, financial and budgetary control, and educational
            planning to meet the Government's decentralization
            policies. (3) Improvement in the Quality of Secondary
            Education could be accomplished by initiating an in-depth
            study of the present status and needs of secondary
            education, a two-phase pilot program of computer-assisted
            education, curriculum revision, and teacher/administrator training.

docna.cdata!: Costa Rica - Basic Education Rehabilitation Project

Costa Rica - Basic Education
